description: The Citation Resource enables reference to any knowledge artifact for purposes of identification and attribution. The Citation Resource supports existing reference structures and developing publication practices such as versioning, expressing complex contributorship roles, and referencing computable resources.

constraint.human: Name should be usable as an identifier for the module by machine processing applications such as code generation

element.definition: The Citation Resource enables reference to any knowledge artifact for purposes of identification and attribution. The Citation Resource supports existing reference structures and developing publication practices such as versioning, expressing complex contributorship roles, and referencing computable resources.
element.short: A description of identification, location, or contributorship of a publication (article or artifact)

element.comment: Can be a urn:uuid: or a urn:oid: but real http: addresses are preferred. Multiple instances may share the same URL if they have a distinct version.
element.definition: An absolute URI that is used to identify this citation when it is referenced in a specification, model, design or an instance; also called its canonical identifier. This SHOULD be globally unique and SHOULD be a literal address at which at which an authoritative instance of this summary is (or will be) published. This URL can be the target of a canonical reference. It SHALL remain the same when the summary is stored on different servers.
element.requirements: Allows the citation to be referenced by a single globally unique identifier.
element.short: Canonical identifier for this citation, represented as a globally unique URI

element.comment: May include DOI, PMID, PMCID, etc. This element will contain unique identifiers that support de-duplication of citations. This identifier can be valid for only one citation resource.
element.definition: A formal identifier that is used to identify this citation when it is represented in other formats, or referenced in a specification, model, design or an instance.
element.requirements: Allows externally provided and/or usable identifiers to be associated with this citation.
element.short: Identifier for the Citation resource itself

element.comment: There may be different citation instances that have the same identifier but different versions.  The version can be appended to the url in a reference to allow a reference to a particular business version of the citation with the format [url]|[version].
element.definition: The identifier that is used to identify this version of the citation when it is referenced in a specification, model, design or instance. This is an arbitrary value managed by the citation author and is not expected to be globally unique. For example, it might be a timestamp (e.g. yyyymmdd) if a managed version is not available. There is also no expectation that versions can be placed in a lexicographical sequence.
element.short: Business version of the citation

element.comment: The name is not expected to be globally unique. The name should be a simple alphanumeric type name to ensure that it is machine-processing friendly.
element.definition: A natural language name identifying the citation. This name should be usable as an identifier for the module by machine processing applications such as code generation.
element.requirements: Support human navigation and code generation.
element.short: Name for this citation (computer friendly)

element.comment: This name does not need to be machine-processing friendly and may contain punctuation, white-space, etc.
element.definition: A short, descriptive, user-friendly title for the citation.
element.short: Name for this citation (human friendly)

element.comment: Allows filtering of summarys s that are appropriate for use versus not.
element.definition: The status of this summary. Enables tracking the life-cycle of the content.
element.isModifierReason: This is labeled as "Is Modifier" because applications should not use a retired {{title}} without due consideration
element.requirements: Allows filtering of citations that are appropriate for use versus not.
element.short: draft | active | retired | unknown

element.comment: Allows filtering of citations that are appropriate for use versus not.
element.definition: A Boolean value to indicate that this citation is authored for testing purposes (or education/evaluation/marketing) and is not intended to be used for genuine usage.
element.requirements: Enables experimental content to be developed following the same lifecycle that would be used for a production-level citation.
element.short: For testing purposes, not real usage

element.comment: Note that this is not the same as the resource last-modified-date, since the resource may be a secondary representation of the citation. Additional specific dates may be added as extensions or be found by consulting Provenances associated with past versions of the resource.
element.definition: The date  (and optionally time) when the citation was published. The date must change when the business version changes and it must change if the status code changes. In addition, it should change when the substantive content of the citation changes.
element.short: Date last changed

element.comment: Usually an organization but may be an individual. The publisher (or steward) of the citation is the organization or individual primarily responsible for the maintenance and upkeep of the citation. This is not necessarily the same individual or organization that developed and initially authored the content. The publisher is the primary point of contact for questions or issues with the citation. This item SHOULD be populated unless the information is available from context.
element.definition: The name of the organization or individual that published the citation.
element.requirements: Helps establish the "authority/credibility" of the citation.  May also allow for contact.
element.short: The publisher of the Citation, not the publisher of the article or artifact being cited

element.comment: May be a web site, an email address, a telephone number, etc.
element.definition: Contact details to assist a user in finding and communicating with the publisher.
element.short: Contact details for the publisher of the Citation Resource

element.comment: This description can be used to capture details such as why the citation was built, comments about misuse, instructions for clinical use and interpretation, literature references, examples from the paper world, etc. It is not a rendering of the citation as conveyed in the 'text' field of the resource itself. This item SHOULD be populated unless the information is available from context (e.g. the language of the citation is presumed to be the predominant language in the place the citation was created).
element.definition: A free text natural language description of the citation from a consumer's perspective.
element.short: Natural language description of the citation

element.comment: When multiple useContexts are specified, there is no expectation that all or any of the contexts apply.
element.definition: The content was developed with a focus and intent of supporting the contexts that are listed. These contexts may be general categories (gender, age, ...) or may be references to specific programs (insurance plans, studies, ...) and may be used to assist with indexing and searching for appropriate citation instances.
element.requirements: Assist in searching for appropriate content.
element.short: The context that the Citation Resource content is intended to support

element.comment: It may be possible for the citation to be used in jurisdictions other than those for which it was originally designed or intended.
element.definition: A legal or geographic region in which the citation is intended to be used.
element.short: Intended jurisdiction for citation (if applicable)

element.comment: This element does not describe the usage of the citation. Instead, it provides traceability of ''why'' the resource is either needed or ''why'' it is defined as it is.  This may be used to point to source materials or specifications that drove the structure of this citation.
element.definition: Explanation of why this citation is needed and why it has been designed as it has.
element.short: Why this citation is defined

element.definition: Use and/or publishing restrictions for the Citation, not for the cited artifact.
element.short: Use and/or publishing restrictions for the Citation, not for the cited artifact

element.comment: The 'date' element may be more recent than the approval date because of minor changes or editorial corrections.
element.definition: The date on which the resource content was approved by the publisher. Approval happens once when the content is officially approved for usage.
element.short: When the citation was approved by publisher

element.comment: If specified, this date follows the original approval date.
element.definition: The date on which the resource content was last reviewed. Review happens periodically after approval but does not change the original approval date.
element.requirements: Gives a sense of how "current" the content is.  Resources that have not been reviewed in a long time may have a risk of being less appropriate/relevant.
element.short: When the citation was last reviewed

element.comment: The effective period for a citation  determines when the content is applicable for usage and is independent of publication and review dates. For example, a measure intended to be used for the year 2016 might be published in 2015.
element.definition: The period during which the citation content was or is planned to be in active use.
element.requirements: Allows establishing a transition before a resource comes into effect and also allows for a sunsetting  process when new versions of the citation are or are expected to be used instead.
element.short: When the citation is expected to be used

element.definition: The identifier that is used to identify this version of the citation when it is referenced in a specification, model, design or instance. This is an arbitrary value managed by the citation author and is not expected to be globally unique. For example, it might be a timestamp (e.g. yyyymmdd) if a managed version is not available. There is also no expectation that versions can be placed in a lexicographical sequence.
element.short: Business version of the citation

element.comment: The name is not expected to be globally unique. The name should be a simple alphanumeric type name to ensure that it is machine-processing friendly.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: A natural language name identifying the citation. This name should be usable as an identifier for the module by machine processing applications such as code generation.
element.requirements: Support human navigation and code generation.
element.short: Name for this citation (computer friendly)

element.comment: This name does not need to be machine-processing friendly and may contain punctuation, white-space, etc.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: A short, descriptive, user-friendly title for the citation.
element.short: Name for this citation (human friendly)

element.comment: Allows filtering of summarys s that are appropriate for use versus not.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: The status of this summary. Enables tracking the life-cycle of the content.
element.isModifierReason: This is labeled as "Is Modifier" because applications should not use a retired {{title}} without due consideration
element.requirements: Allows filtering of citations that are appropriate for use versus not.
element.short: draft | active | retired | unknown

element.short: For testing purposes, not real usage

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: The date  (and optionally time) when the citation was published. The date must change when the business version changes and it must change if the status code changes. In addition, it should change when the substantive content of the citation changes.
element.short: Date last changed

element.comment: Usually an organization but may be an individual. The publisher (or steward) of the citation is the organization or individual primarily responsible for the maintenance and upkeep of the citation. This is not necessarily the same individual or organization that developed and initially authored the content. The publisher is the primary point of contact for questions or issues with the citation. This item SHOULD be populated unless the information is available from context.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.definition: The name of the organization or individual that published the citation.
element.requirements: Helps establish the "authority/credibility" of the citation.  May also allow for contact.

status ?!Σ1..1codedraft | active | retired | unknown

effectivePeriod Σ0..1PeriodWhen the citation is expected to be used
author 0..*ContactDetailWho authored the Citation
editor 0..*ContactDetailWho edited the Citation
reviewer 0..*ContactDetailWho reviewed the Citation
